Award.AwardTitle: Neural and cognitive changes in aging and bilingualism: Implications for language production and executive function

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. As people live longer, their lives are more impacted by age-related cognitive changes. Older adults cite word-finding difficulties as their number one memory complaint, making communication increasingly difficult for them. Research on the source of age-related word retrieval problems has focused on changes in the mapping between word meaning and word form. The planned research explores how cognitive abilities, such as executive function, and the pathways in the brain supporting language and cognitive functions contribute to language production in older age. Taking advantage of the unique language demands placed on bilinguals, this interdisciplinary project combines theories and methods from linguistics, psychology, and cognitive neuroscience to examine the long-term effects of lifelong bilingualism on language production, executive functions, and the neural structures supporting them. The proposed research will advance our understanding not only of age-related changes in language production, but also of the the neural structures supporting executive function and language. As a community with a large Hispanic and bilingual population, Riverside, California is an ideal setting for studying younger and older bilingual adults and for training and mentoring undergraduate students who come from groups that are underrepresented in science.

The goals of the proposed research are to investigate factors reflecting lifelong language experiences and their effects on cognitive and language functioning in older bilingual and monolingual adults. A specific goal is to investigate the effects of bilingualism on white matter pathways in the brain, particularly those involved in language and higher-order cognitive processes. Past research has demonstrated that the unique cognitive demands imposed by the lifelong use of two languages results in enhancements in executive control and protections against the symptoms of cognitive impairment and dementia in the elderly. Little is known about the long-term effects of these executive control enhancements on language production. In the proposed research, we investigate how lifelong bilingualism affects word retrieval processes in older adults and ask if the potential advantages observed for cognitive control also serve to help older bilingual adults compensate for language declines in aging. Using behavioral and structural neuroimaging methods, we explore the neural substrates of lexical retrieval and executive control in older adults who have used two languages throughout their lives and those who have used a single language. The project integrates research on bilingualism that considers the consequences of dual language use for spoken language and for cognition, together with research on cognition, language, and neural change in aging.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project is to investigate what impact bilingualism might have on language and cognitive changes associated with healthy aging. The study also investigates age-related changes to brain structure and whether bilingualism is associated with a preservation of brain structure and/or function in older age in brain areas related to cognition and language control. More generally, this project aims to uncover the brain patterns associated with language production success in older age, particularly for brain areas involved in language and cognitive control. 

We developed a large battery of language and cognitive tasks that would address our specific research questions. Brain structure measures were obtained with Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), and brain function measures were obtained with electrophysiology (EEG) during specific tasks. We tested older and younger adult monolingual English speakers and older and younger adult Spanish-English bilinguals.

Among bilinguals, we found an asymmetry in the amount of interference they experienced during language processing tasks: interference was greater when performing in the non-dominant language than in the dominant language. However, when comparing bilinguals and monolinguals, we found that bilinguals were better able to deal with attentional interference than monolinguals. Another novel finding from this study was that bilinguals process cognate words (words that are similar in both languages, such as bicycle in English and bicicleta in Spanish) in ways that challenge the understanding of cognate words as easier to process than non-cognates. Specifically, we found evidence that cognate words are easier to retrieve in some ways but that they produce interference later in the time-course of word processing. These studies of language processing shed light on how the unique mental architecture of bilingualism impacts language processing and what kinds of cognitive mechanisms are called upon to deal with cross-language interference.

We have just begun analyzing the results of the brain structure measures. Our first set of analyses has revealed that bilinguals in our study had thinner cortex in specific regions of the brain related to resistance to proactive interference compared to monolinguals. Furthermore, bilinguals showed a positive relationship between the integrity of specific white matter pathways and their resistance to proactive interference. These results help us to uncover how bilingualism impacts brain structure and what the behavioral consequences of those effects are. 

With the findings from the current study, we can begin to understand how word retrieval processes change with older age and how cognitive control may be used to help older adults compensate for word retrieval difficulties. The relationship between brain structure and function and individuals’ performance on behavioral tasks measuring language and cognitive processes is still unclear. With the comparison of both older and younger adults and monolinguals and bilinguals, we have begun to disentangle the effects of aging and bilingualism on brain structure and language abilities.

This research fills in several gaps in our understanding of language processing. First, most theoretical models and language assessments are designed for monolinguals. These may not be appropriate for the accurate assessment of bilinguals. Our data can provide information about age-related changes in monolinguals and bilinguals separately in order to determine the effect of aging on different populations. Furthermore, we show that cross-language influence is a key aspect of bilingual processing and must be integrated into any model or assessment of language in bilinguals. This project has also trained dozens of undergraduate students who come from bilingual homes and contributed their knowledge to this scientific endeavor. Many of these students have continued to pursue advanced degrees or have brought their knowledge and training into a variety of careers where they can make a positive impact on their communities.
